NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
J. Capacity and Level of Service Analysis
O. Right of Way Impacts & Cost Estimate
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
NJ Route 31 is a state facility that begins in Trenton and travels north through three
counties in western New Jersey to its northern terminus with U.S. Route 46. NJ Route
31 provides a key link between Interstate 78 in northern Hunterdon County, U.S. Route
202 in Raritan Township, and Interstate 95 just north of Trenton. As such, NJ Route 31
helps serve as one of the few regional north-south connections in this part of New
Jersey. The portion of Route 31 within the project limits lies in the Township of Raritan
in Hunterdon County, and is functionally classified by NJDOT as an urban principal
arterial with the number of lanes varying between two and five.
In late 2008, a Feasibility Assessment study was initiated for a section of Route 31
between Church Street (MP 22.21) and River Road (MP 25.26). In early 2009, the
Commissioner received a letter from the current Deputy Mayor and former Mayor of
Raritan Township, John King, indicating that the current roadway configuration of
northbound Route 31 at Minneakoning Road (MP 23.84) creates “a dangerous traffic
pattern”. The Township’s Police Chief said “the abrupt termination of the merge lane at
the Minneakoning intersection is dangerous and unacceptable. It's an invitation for
In response to the letter, DPD investigated the situation and observed vehicles
behaving in a pattern generally consistent with the Mayor’s and Police Chief’s
observations and concerns. It appears that multiple problems occur. Some drivers use
the second lane as a means to pass queued traffic in the thru lane and then “force” their
way in near or at the intersection. Other drivers seem unaware of the need to merge
until they are at or near the intersection creating sudden stops and merges. Potentially
contributing to the issue, is that it is not uncommon for the northbound Route 31 queues
at Minneakoning Road to extend beyond the merge signs, thus drivers who are
unfamiliar with the roadway realize they need to merge at a point where traffic is queued
in the other lane resulting in a more difficult merge.
This current roadway configuration of Route 31 northbound at Minneakoning is a result
of roadway changes made as part of the Raritan Town Square Development Major
As part of the agreement, the developers of the Raritan Town Square extended the
second northbound Route 31 thru lane, previously ending shortly after Walter Foran
Drive, to Minneakoning Road. It had been DPD’s and Major Access’ intention that the
second thru lane extend beyond Minneakoning; however, in the final “fair share”
agreement the second lane terminated as a right-turn only lane at Minneakoning Road.
In May 2009, a “breakout” of the overall Route 31 FA project was approved for project
development. The breakout project limits extended from Minneakoning Road to
Prestige Plaza (MP 24.73). The expectation was to advance the breakout project as a
“quick fix” Pipeline 3 project. The intent of the breakout was to address the safety
issues while limiting ROW width and the potential impacts possible due to existing
conditions (i.e., an existing fill section with side slopes south of the Bartles Corner
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Intersection). Additionally, the goal was to advance this project at a rapid pace with an
advertisement date set for the fall of 2010.
The overall purpose of the Route 31 FA project is to improve safety conditions and
reduce existing and projected congestion and delay along the corridor. The proposed
breakout project has the same project purpose with a focus on addressing safety issues
at the intersection of Route 31 and Minneakoning Road.
Crash analysis was completed for NJ Route 31 within approximately the breakout
project limits. Based on data from 2005 through 2007, within the approximate one (1)
mile section of Route 31, there were 162 crashes. The crash rate for this section
In addition to the safety concerns, vehicles traveling in this section of Route 31
experience excessive delays and queues at several locations including the intersections
of NJ Route 31 with Minneakoning Road (LOS F) and Bartles Corner Road (LOS E), as
well as at lane drop locations where travel lanes are reduced from two lanes to one lane
per direction. These conditions are projected to significantly deteriorate as anticipated
and future development occurs in and around the corridor.
There were four different alternatives that were generated for the Feasibility
Assessment portion of this project. These four alternatives, which are described in
more detail in Section II: Alternatives Analysis, were designated as follows:
Alternative 1 – Minneakoning Road to Wescott Drive
Alternative 2 – Minneakoning Road to Healthquest Boulevard
Alternative 2A – Minneakoning Road to Prestige Plaza
Alternative 3 – Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Comments from Local Officials and Scope Team members resulted in Alternative 3
being selected as the IPA. The implementation of the IPA would address the Town’s
concerns at Minneakoning Road expressed in the letter to the Commissioner. This
alternative, as shown through the results of simulation analysis, also addresses the
Town’s and County’s concerns that a solution that did not extend beyond Bartles Corner
The IPA selected as part of the Feasibility Assessment portion of this project is
recommended for advancement as a Pipeline 3 project.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
This project is referred to as NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements,
This project is designated as Classification 3, Widening and Resurfacing per
NJDOT Construction Cost Estimating Guide, Appendix C, Table C-1. This
project is also categorized as General Construction, work type code GENC as
per NJDOT Construction Estimate Guidelines, Appendix A, Table A-1.
The following provides a consolidated timeline for key project events:
Problem Statement identifies the need to improve southbound
Route 31 between East Main Street and Church Street. Locals
identify similar safety and operational problems along the Route
31 Corridor between Church Street and Bartles Corner Road.
Division of Project Planning and Development initiates a
Concept Development (CD) Study for Route 31 between Church
Initiation of Feasibility Assessment (FA) Study for Route 31
between Church Street and Bartles Corner Road
Jan. 2009: NJDOT Commissioner receives a letter from Raritan Township
Deputy Mayor John King identifying traffic/geometric concerns
Jan-May 2009: DPD conducts field investigation and a traffic/geometric
evaluation of the intersection of Minneakoning and Rt 31.
A breakout from the overall Route 31 FA project (Route 31
Northbound, Minneakoning Road to M.P. 24.73) is approved
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Following an evaluation of existing conditions, the following needs have been
Improve Safety: The current roadway configuration of northbound Route 31 at
Minneakoning Road creates an undesirable traffic condition. Additionally,
there is a high number of crashes along the corridor particularly at the
signalized intersections, lane drop locations and merge points.
Reduce Current and Future Congestion and Delay: Currently, there are
excessive delays and queuing at the intersections of NJ Route 31 with
Minneakoning Road and Bartles Corner Road, as well as at the lane drop
locations where travel lanes reduce from two per direction to one per direction.
These conditions are projected to significantly deteriorate as approved,
anticipated and future development occurs in and around the corridor.
The project limits extend from Minneakoning Road (M.P. 23.84) to
approximately 1000’ beyond (M.P.24.94) the signalized intersection at the
The portion of Route 31 within the project limits lies in the Township of Raritan
in Hunterdon County. The limits of the study area have been identified on the
attached Project Location Map illustrated as Figure 1.
The Project Manager for this project is John Molé.

page.text: During the data collection phase of this project, specific sources were
consulted to obtain information on existing conditions in the study area. This
information was evaluated to determine areas of non-conformance with current
design standards and also formed the base data for use during the
development of improvement alternatives. Table 1 provides a list of the data
NJ Route 31 Intersection Improvements at Church Street
A Core Group Meetings was held on October 2, 2009 at NJDOT in
Trenton, NJ. The results of the meeting are documented in the meeting
Additionally, as part of the background information, the project limits were
checked with the following Management Systems:
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Pavement Management System Information for this section of Route 31
was not provided. Visual inspection of the roadway suggests that the
roadway surface is in good to fair condition. The anticipated scope of
work associated with this effort will include reconstruction and resurfacing
of the existing roadway for the project limits.
There are two structures within the project area. The first structure (No.
1012153) is a culvert that crosses under Route 31 at Minneakoning Creek
and the second structure (No. 1012154) is a culvert that crosses under
Route 31 at Assiscong Creek. These structures will not be impacted by
the proposed alternatives nor was any Management Systems information
given for these structures for this report, as they were recently
reconstructed during the Route 31 Section 6D project.
Based on the NJDOT Bureau of Systems Development & Analysis CMS
Priority Ranking, the corridor links rank from Medium to High priority.
Within the project limits, the two links volume to capacity (v/c) ratios are
0.96 and 1.03. These v/c ratios indicate a priority ranking of 8 and 17 out
of 167 as far congested links within the county. The CMS Priority Ranking
table can be found in Appendix H (Management System Information).
No DMS information was provided for the project limits.
At the time of the report, no maintenance projects were planned within the
As part of the process of selecting the IPA, DPD sought input from both
internal and external stakeholders through presentations and meetings.
The project was presented to the Raritan Township Local Officials in June
of 2009. A Public Information Center was held at Raritan Township Police
Building on December 14, 2009 to present the IPA to the public for their
The results of the meetings and the public information center summary are
compiled in Appendix B (Coordination and Correspondence).
A copy of the Township’s Resolution of Support is provided in Appendix
The overall purpose of the Route 31 FA project is to improve safety
conditions and reduce existing and projected congestion and delay along
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
the corridor. The proposed breakout project has the same project purpose
with a focus at addressing the issues at Minneakoning Road.
Crash analysis was completed for NJ Route 31 within approximately the
breakout project limits. Based on data from 2005 through 2007, within the
approximate one (1) mile section of Route 31, there were 163 crashes.
The crash rate for this section exceeds the statewide average by 89%.
In addition to the safety concerns, vehicles traveling in this section of
Route 31 experience excessive delays and queues at several locations
including the intersections of NJ Route 31 with Minneakoning Road (LOS
F) and Bartles Corner Road (LOS E), as well as at lane drop locations
where travel lanes reduce from two per direction to one per direction.
These conditions are projected to significantly deteriorate as anticipated
and future development occurs in and around the corridor.
NJ Route 31 has both a local and regional significance. From a regional
perspective, NJ Route 31 serves as a key link between I-95 in the south
and I-78 and I-80 in the north. As such, NJ Route 31 provides one of the
few regional north-south connections in this part of New Jersey making it
an attractive and important route for regional traffic. From a local
perspective, NJ Route 31 provides local significance since it serves as the
main arterial through this portion of Raritan Township and has a mix of
commercial, medical, residential and educational development along the

text.b: b. State Development and Redevelopment Plan (SDRP)

page.text: The State Development and Redevelopment Plan (SDRP) use a
classification system to map the entire State into appropriate “planning
areas” and contain associated policies and recommendations for each
area. The NJ Route 31 corridor (and land bordering NJ Route 31) within
the project limits is completely within Fringe Planning Area, PA3.
The Fringe Planning Area is defined as a predominantly rural landscape
that is not prime agricultural or environmentally sensitive land, with
scattered small communities and freestanding residential, commercial and
industrial development. The intent of Fringe Planning Areas is:
1. Protect environment-culturally, as a resource and as a buffer to
2. Accommodate new growth in existing centers or proposed centers
(which includes sewer and public water services)
3. Protect the character of the area
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
4. Infrastructure, in centers, should be provided by the private sector
except where joint public/private investment would benefit the
The Statewide Development Re-Development Plan can be found in
The project is located in an area that displays a range of development
patterns from the historic mixed use grid pattern of Flemington, to the
commercial strip development along NJ Route 31 and U.S. Route 202.
There are a number of developments either in the planning stages or
Redevelopment as the Raritan Town Square, the expansion to the
Hunterdon Medical Center, the expansion to the Health Quest
Development, and the introduction of new stores and development at the
Prestige Plaza. In addition, there are several smaller developments
planned for parcels either adjacent to NJ Route 31, or on roadways which
The existing NJ Route 31 corridor in this section varies between two (2)
and five (5) lanes, with shoulders of varying width. New Jersey State
Highway Access Management Code assigns NJ Route 31 in this section a
DTS of 4A which is 4 lanes, divided with shoulders or parking. Within the
study area, some sections of NJ Route 31 do not satisfy the suggested

text.b: b. Characteristics of the Roadway and Surrounding Area

page.text: NJ Route 31 is a state facility that begins in Trenton and travels north
through three counties in western New Jersey to its northern terminus with
U.S. Route 46. NJ Route 31 provides a key link between Interstate 78 in
northern Hunterdon County, U.S. Route 202 in Raritan Township, and
Interstate 95 just north of Trenton. As such, NJ Route 31 helps serve as
one of the few regional north-south connections in this part of New Jersey.
The portion of Route 31 within the project limits lies in the Township of
Raritan in Hunterdon County, and is functionally classified by NJDOT as
an urban principal arterial with the number of lanes varying between two
Flemington Borough and Raritan Township are home to a large number of
retail stores and shopping outlets. The stores are located along NJ Route
31 and US Route 202 as well as in Flemington Borough. Traffic
generated by these retail shops typically travel via US 202, NJ 31 and NJ
12. Motorists accessing the shopping areas from the north utilize the
This section of Route 31 was reconstructed as part of the Route 31
documentation. Following coordination with internal NJDOT Environmental
Staff, the determination was made that an environmental screening was
unnecessary due to the previous CED efforts combined with the
environmental coordination associated with the Flemington Bypass and
Consultation with SHPO was completed on 10/20/09 for the current CED
effort. A copy of the consultation letter is provided in Appendix B.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
The purpose of this section is to evaluate physical roadway features and
to cite all existing roadway deficiencies with respect to conformance of
current roadway design standards. The evaluation of the roadway
deficiencies was conducted using the NJDOT Roadway Design Manual,
available plans, and field observation data.
In accordance with the Roadway Design Manual (RDM), Table 2-1
(Sec. 2-03.3), the existing 45 and 50 mph speed limits along NJ Route
31 result in design speeds of 50 and 55 mph respectively. In
accordance with Table 4-5 (Sec. 4-03.3) the standard curve radii for
urban highways with the above described design speeds are 926 and
A review of the available record drawings shows that there are a total
of five (5) horizontal curves within the project limits. The existing
curves and their properties are described in Table 2 below.
A review of the existing plans shows no horizontal curvature within the
limits of the project that are substandard.
The NJDOT Roadway Design Manual (Sec. 4-04.4) specifies a
minimum grade rate of 0.3% for freeways and land service highways.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Review of the information gathered from our survey indicates an
existing profile that exceeds the minimum.
The NJDOT design criteria (Sec. 4-04.5) states the minimum
allowable length of curve based on stopping sight distance is
calculated by multiplying the algebraic difference in grades entering
and exiting the vertical curve by K. The value K is the horizontal
distance required to effect a percent change in gradient and is
dependent on both design speed and type of curve (sag or crest).
Additionally, flat vertical curves should be evaluated for aesthetics,
drainage and rideability. In a crest curve, the minimum length should
desirably be three (3) times the design speed (for English units). In a
sag curve, the minimum length of curve should desirably be
L = Length of sag vertical curve, ft.
A = Algebraic difference in grades, percent.
A review of the available record drawings shows that there are a total
of five (5) vertical curves within the project limits. The existing curves
and their properties are described in Table 3.
Based on the record drawings and the above calculations, there is
one curve that is deficient for sight distance.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Within the limits of the project, NJ Route 31 consists of a two lane
section with no passing permitted, a three lane section with a two-way
left turn lane, and four and five lane sections. Since passing sight
distance is considered only on two-lane roads where passing is
permitted, there is no need to evaluate passing sight distance on this
Stopping Sight Distance on Horizontal Curves
The evaluation of stopping sight distance on horizontal curves is
based on the clear distance from the centerline of the inside lane of
the curve to some type of obstruction. The minimum stopping sight
distance is then computed based on the design speed of the roadway.
The existing curves and their stopping sight distance values are

i.b: Table 4: Stopping Sight Distance on Horizontal Curves

page.text: Based on stopping sight distance calculations, record drawings and
field visits, NJ Route 31 does not have any objects or physical
features that would obstruct drivers stopping sight distance.
Stopping Sight Distance on Vertical Curves
The stopping sight distance criteria for vertical curves are based on
the design speed, the length of curve and the algebraic difference in
tangent grades. The existing curves and their stopping sight distance

page.text: Based on the record drawings and the above calculations, there is
one curve that is deficient for stopping sight distance on vertical
The sight distance criteria at a signalized intersection provides some
view in the case of signal violation, permitted right turn on red
The DMR (Sec. 6-03.4) specifies the minimum intersection sight
distance should be at least equal to the stopping sight distance. The
stopping sight distances required on NJ Route 31 for design speeds
of 50 and 55 mph are 425 and 495 feet respectively. The results of
the signalized intersection sight distance review are provided in Table

i.b: Table 6: Stopping Sight Distance at Signalized Intersections

NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Based on the record drawings and field observations, there is one (1)
intersection that is deficient for stopping sight distance.
Minimum intersection sight distance (ISD) is required at all non-
signalized intersections and for any free flowing moves associated
with a signalized intersection, in order to ensure that a motorist may
safely enter of exit the State Highway System.
The required ISD value varies based upon the mainline design speed,
type of vehicle maneuver, and type of traffic control imposed on the
side road traffic. As a minimum, stopping sight distance (SSD) must
be provided at each intersection. As describe above in the section for
SSD at signalized intersections, the SSD for design speeds of 50 and
55 mph are 425 and 495 respectively. The results of the unsignalized
ISD review are provided in Table 7.

i.b: Table 7: Stopping Sight Distance at Unsignalized Intersections

page.text: The existing Route 31 surface types were ascertained through review
of the record drawings obtained from NJDOT. The plans indicate that
the roadway consists of a 2” Superpave Surface Course, 9”
Superpave Base Course, 8” Dense Graded Aggregate, and 8’
The RDM (Sec. 5-02) indicates the roadway cross slope pavement
should be at a minimum 1.5 percent.
The available record plans for Route 31 shows the slopes along the
The RDM (Sec. 5-03) indicated that lane widths on land service
highways should be no less than 11 feet. Based on record drawings
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
and field observations, lane widths within the project limits meet or
exceed the minimum set forth by the RDM.
The RDM (Sec. 5-04.2) indicates that shoulder widths on land service
highways should not be less than eight (8) feet. Based on record
drawings and field observations, there are no areas within the project
limits that have shoulder widths which are below the 8 foot minimum
The area between the roadway and the highway right of way is
referred to as the roadside or border. Depending on the median,
traveled way and shoulder widths, the roadside width is in the range
of 70ft. for rural freeways and 25ft. for urban highways.
The roadside/border width varies from 22’ to 146’ throughout the
Based on visual inspection, the curb throughout the project limits
appears to be in good condition. Those areas that do not have
existing curb do show signs of runoff channel forming at the edge of
Sidewalks are located at very few locations throughout the project
area. The areas where sidewalks exist appear to be in good
There are no existing medians within the project limits.
There are no bridges within the project limits.
According to Figure 6-J (Sec. 6-04.1) of the roadway design manual,
the minimum skew angle of an intersection is 60 degrees. For
intersection skew angles of less than 60 degrees, channelization
should be provided. The intersections along NJ Route 31 and their
associated skew angles can be seen in Table 8.

There are no existing interchanges within the project limits.
Within the project limits, the speed limit on Route 31 varies between
Within the project limits, NJ Route 31 traverses a predominately
commercial area with a few residential areas mixed in. Given the
design speed, roadside slope and design ADT, the clear zone may be
determined. The clear zone for NJ Route 31 is 18-24 feet (Fig. 8-A)
as per the RDM. Field observations revealed that, throughout the
project study area along NJ Route 31, there are unprotected utility
poles, road signs, signal poles, trees, and steep grade changes
There is guide rail sporadically along both the northbound and
southbound NJ Route 31 and appears to be in good condition.
NJ Route 31 has varying edge of road treatments throughout the
project area. The edge of road varies back and forth between curbed
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Several sub-watersheds of the Raritan River Watershed are within the
project limits. There are six sub-watersheds including the (1) Raritan
River at the roadway project northern limits, and crosses several
Raritan River tributaries sequentially traveling south as follows: (2)
unnamed tributary, (3) Assicong Creek, (4) Minneakoning Creek, (5)
Bushkill Creek, and (6) Bushkill Brook. These streams are carried
under NJ Route 31 by culverts which are located at M.P. 22.63
No. n/a), and M.P. 25.13 (Structure No. n/a).
For the break-out project, sub-watershed areas include (1) Raritan
River at the roadway project northern limits, and crosses several
Raritan River tributaries sequentially traveling south as follows: (2)
unnamed tributary, (3) Assicong Creek, and (4) Minneakoning Creek.
Field visits to the project area revealed no issues with highway
lighting. A review of the available crash reports did not indicate a
crash problem due to poor highway lighting.
Field visits to the project area have revealed adequate signing within
the project area, and signs appear to be in good condition.
Based on field observations, the existing pavement markings appear
to be in good to average condition on the project roadways.
Based on visual inspection for the break-out section the pavement
condition was good to fair. The scope of work is anticipated to
resurface and/or reconstruct pavements within the project limits.
As part of the access review process, the existing conditions of the
driveways were examined for compliance with provisions of the New
Jersey State Highway Access Management Code, dated August
2003. A copy of the applicable pages of the Access Management
Code, indicating the Access Level (AL) and Desirable Typical Section
(DTS), is included as Appendix E for the portion of Route 31 located
The existing Route 31 corridor varies between a three lane to a five
lane undivided sections with a two-way left turn lane.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
A review of the Access Code reveals that the DTS for this portion of
Route 31 is a 4A and that the AL is 3 (M.P. 22.02 – 24.40) and 2
(M.P. 24.40 – 30.26). A DTS of 4A specifies a section containing 4
lanes, divided with shoulders or parking. An AL of 3 indicates right
turn access with provision for left-turn access via jug handle and an
AL of 2 indicates access along street or interchange only. The
existing Route 31 does not satisfy this DTS throughout the entire
The following indicates specific parcels which are in non-conformance
with provisions of the Access Code:
Section 16:47-3.8(c) of the Access Code requires a minimum edge of
clearance of 12 feet. This is measured from the extended lot line
along the curbline to the beginning of the curbline opening. Several
properties within the project limits have inadequate edge clearance
Section 16:47-3.8(d) of the Access Code lists minimum and maximum
curbline opening for residential and non-residential properties. The
maximum allowable curbline opening for residential and non-
residential properties is 30 feet and 50 feet respectively. There are no
properties that are in non-conformance for curbline opening.
Section 16:47-3.8(k) of the Access Code lists the minimum corner
clearance for signalized and unsignalized intersection. The corner
clearance should be measured between the end of the curb return of
the intersecting street and the beginning of the curb return or
beginning of the depressed curb for the driveway. A minimum of 50
feet for all driveways in the vicinity of unsignalized intersections is
required as well as 100 feet for those driveways in the vicinity of a
signalized intersection. All access points within the project limits fall
The NJDOT, the county engineer and the township engineer were
contacted to ascertain the names of the utility companies, which have
facilities within the project limits. The utility companies and their
corresponding contact information can be seen in Table 9.

The New Jersey Department of Transportation (NJDOT) currently has
jurisdiction over NJ Route 31. Hunterdon County currently has
jurisdiction over CR 600 (Wescott Dr.), CR 652 (Gauntt Pl.), and CR
612 (Bartles Corner Rd./Sand Hill Rd.). All remaining intersecting
roads within the project limits are under the jurisdiction of Raritan
A review of the NJDOT Pedestrian Compatible Planning and Design
Guidelines was conducted in the evaluation of this project. These
guidelines indicate that for a facility with a posted speed of 40 mph or
a truck, bus, or recreational vehicle percentage over 5%, paved
shoulder widths beyond 4 feet are desirable and should be considered
for the pedestrian compatibility requirements. The portion of NJ
Route 31 within the project limits contains a shoulder width of at least
4 feet. This portion of NJ Route 31 is therefore compatible.
A review of the NJDOT Pedestrian Compatible Planning and Design
Guidelines was conducted in the evaluation of this project. These
guidelines indicate that for a facility with an Average Annual Daily
Traffic (ADDT) over 10,000 or a truck percentage over 5%, a posted
speed of 40mph, and located within an urban area, the bicycle
compatibility requirements would necessitate a 4 foot shoulder. Also
it is noted that where possible, NJDOT minimum shoulder width of 8
feet should be provided on roadways having an ADDT greater than
The portion of NJ Route 31 within the project limits is compatible.

the southbound side of Route 31 and should not be impacted by this
The landscape in the vicinity of NJ Route 31 consists of mostly grass
There are no existing structures or bridges within the limits of the
project. Refer to subsection (e) Culverts for culvert information.
There are no existing noise walls within the project limits.
There are no existing retaining walls within the project limits.
There are no existing sign structures within the project limits.
During the Route 31 Section 6D project, culverts within the project
limits were improved. Within the study area, there are three culverts.
Of the three culverts one qualifies to be ranked based on NJDOT
criteria (20 foot span, highway carrying). This structure (structure
number 1012154, built in 2005) has a priority ranking 5 - the lowest. It
is in very good to excellent condition. The remaining two structures
within the project limits are not ranked as they are less than 20 feet
Within the project area, there are four signalized intersections and two un-
signalized intersections. The number of travel lanes ranges from two to
five. Currently, there are excessive delays and queues at a number of
intersections, as well as at lane drop locations.
Traffic counts and field observations were conducted to help understand
the traffic flow characteristics and problematic traffic operations. Field
observations consisted of queuing and safety concerns, signal operations,
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
and detailed intersection geometry sketches including lane configurations,
pavement markings, pedestrian feasibility, signage, and local land use.

text.b: b. Capacity and Level of Service of Existing Conditions

page.text: In addition to the studies performed in the field, the simulation software
Synchro/SimTraffic was used to perform existing traffic operations
analyses. The SimTraffic model simulates individual vehicular movements
and congestion-related issues such as the effect of spillback and blocking
at adjacent intersections providing detailed Levels of Service for each
intersection within the study area. The traffic simulation model was
developed and calibrated so that it represented a reasonably accurate
Traffic volumes on NJ Route 31 range between 20,000 to 25,000 ADT.
The signalized intersections along the study corridor are located at
Minneakoning Road, Wescott Drive, Bartles Corner Road and Prestige
Plaza. The NJDOT Congestion Management System ranks the two
corridor links from Medium to High priority with (v/c) ratios of 0.96 and
1.03. These v/c ratios indicate a priority ranking of 8 and 17 out of 167 as
far as congested links within the county.
Tables 10 and 11 provide the LOS results by approach for each
signalized intersections in the project study area.

Table 11: 2007 PM Peak Hour Levels of Service and Delay

page.text: NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
As can be seen in the tables, the intersections with Bartles Corner Road
and Minneakoning Road are operating at or over capacity during the PM
peak hour with average vehicle delays on northbound NJ Route 31
exceeding two minutes at Minneakoning Road. In fact, the average delay
is likely worse than reported since the queue on NJ Route 31 Northbound
frequently extends from Minneakoning Road through the intersection with
The NJDOT, Bureau of Safety Programs provided database crash
summary data for the corridor for the period January 1, 2004 to December
31, 2006. The corridor was divided by cross-section and compared to
statewide averages for similar roadway types. Table 12 shows the crash

i.b: Table 12: NJDOT Bureau of Safety Systems Crash Data

page.text: The larger section, MP 23.51 to MP 24.73, has a crash rate that far
excess the statewide average for roadways with similar cross-sections.
More detailed crash information is provided in Appendix K.
In order to examine the crash information in more detail, crash reports
were requested and received from Raritan Township Police Department
for the period November 2004 to November 2007, which corresponds with
completion of the NJ Route 31 Section 6D construction project. A
comprehensive crash analysis was completed for NJ Route 31 within the
project limits using this data. The corridor was divided into three sections
based on post-construction cross-sections. The results of the analysis are
provided in Table 13. More detailed information is provided in Appendix

A project fact sheet was created for the Core Group Meeting that took place at
NJDOT on October 2, 2009. It should be noted that the alternatives for this
report have been modified since the Core Group Meeting, thus alternative
headings may not agree between the two documents. The project fact sheet
can be found in Appendix C (Project Fact Sheet).
Based on the analysis of existing conditions, the following needs have been
The current roadway configuration of northbound Route 31 at Minneakoning
Road creates an undesirable traffic condition. Additionally, there is a high rate
of crashes along the corridor compared to state averages with a concentration
of the crashes occurring at the signalized intersections, lane drop locations
Reduce Current and Future Congestion and Delay
Currently, there are excessive delays and queuing at the intersections of NJ
Route 31 with Minneakoning Road and Bartles Corner Road, as well as at the
lane drop locations where travel lanes reduce from two per direction to one per
direction. These conditions are projected to significantly deteriorate as
approved, anticipated and future development occurs in and around the
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
A four-step process was used to prepare this analysis. First, the existing
conditions were established for the study area. Project needs were then
identified from the baseline condition. Next, alternatives were developed based
on addressing the project needs. Measures of effectiveness were developed to
select a recommended IPA. Finally, an impact assessment was performed to
determine the cost/benefits of the IPA.
The design standards and controls utilized in the design of the improvement
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
A total of four (4) alternatives were developed to address the project needs of the
study area. The goals of the improvement alternatives are the following:
• Reduce current and future congestion and delay
Illustrations of each of the alternatives have been provided in Appendix L.
Four alternatives were prepared for the Feasibility Assessment portion of the
project. The alternatives differ in the length of the widening of northbound Route 31
with Alternative 1 being the shortest and Alternative 3 being the longest.
Alternative 1 proposes improvements along the northbound side of Route 31
from the intersection at Minneakoning Road (Sta. 1258+00.00) through the
intersection at Wescott Drive tying back into existing shortly after the
intersection (Sta. 1282+50.00). The length of the project is approximately
2450 feet. The proposed typical section consists of two twelve foot (12’) thru
lanes and a four foot (4’) shoulder. The typical section will transition back to
the existing one twelve foot (12’) thru lane and ten foot (10’) shoulder.
This alternative will involve no R.O.W. impacts. Due to the widening of the
roadway there will be 8,960 square feet of additional impervious area and
4,443 square feet of disturbed area due to the construction footprint.
Traffic analysis results for Alternative 1 are provided in Tables 15 and 16.

i.b: Table 15: Alternative 1 AM Peak Hour LOS and Delay (2007 Volumes)

page.text: NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza

i.b: Table 16: Alternative 1 PM Peak Hour LOS and Delay (2007 Volumes)

page.text: The results indicate that the improvements proposed as part of Alternative 1
would improve the overall level of service and delay at the intersection of
Route 31 and Minneakoning Rd. However, the results also indicate that the
other signalized intersections would deteriorate in LOS and delay in the PM
Peak Hour. In other words, the congestion and delay would “shift” from
Minneakoning Road to Bartles Corner Road and Wescott Drive.
Based on a preliminary cost estimate, the construction costs for Alternative 1
Table 17 illustrates the advantages and disadvantages for this alternative.
Adversely impacts the LOS/Delay at other
While Alternative 1 would address the key safety issue on Route 31 at
Minneakoning Road it has significant impacts to the other signalized
intersections in the project area. Essentially, it shifts problems “down the road”
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Alternative 2 proposes improvements to the northbound side of Route 31 from
the intersection of Route 31 at Minneakoning Road (Sta. 1258+00.00) to the
intersection of Route 31 and Healthquest Blvd. (1296+75.00). The length of
the project is approximately 3875 feet. The proposed typical section consists
of two twelve foot (12’) thru lanes and a four foot (4’) shoulder that transitions
back to the existing cross section of one twelve foot (12’) thru lane and a ten
This alternative will involve several R.O.W. impacts which include a permanent
). Due to the widening of the
roadway there will be 13,958 square feet of additional impervious area and
9,458 square feet of disturbed area due to the construction footprint.

Table 19: Alternatives 2 PM Peak Hour LOS and Delay (2007 Volumes)

page.text: NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
As can be seen in the tables, Alternative 2 shows a significantly improved
overall LOS and Delay as compared to the existing conditions for the
intersections of Route 31 and Minneakoning Rd, Wescott Drive, and Bartles
Corner Road with the intersections operating at LOS C or better during both
peak hours. There is a slight increase in the delay at Prestige Plaza which
continues to operate well at LOS B.
Based on a preliminary cost estimate, the construction costs for Alternative 2
Table 20 illustrates the advantages and disadvantages for this alternative.
Larger construction foot print which leads to
Delays will quickly escalate on Route 31 at
Alternative 2 addresses the immediate need at Minneakoning Road and does
not significantly impact the LOS or delay at the other signalized intersection in
the study area. However, there were two key concerns that remained with this
alternative. First, the transitioning of the roadway back to existing is
substandard. The transitioning occurs near Health Quest Boulevard and it
was determined that it would be best to transition prior to the intersection as
oppose to providing a standard length transition with part of the transitioning
occurring through the intersection of Route 31 and Health Quest Blvd.
Second, there was a concern that the favorable LOS conditions for northbound
Route 31 at Prestige Plaza, based on the 2007 traffic volumes, could rapidly
deteriorate if anticipated development at the Plaza occurs.
Alternative 2A was developed to address the substandard transition and is
identical to Alternative 2 except for how it ties back into the existing condition.
Alternative 2a meets the existing condition at the point where the right turn
only lane starts for the Prestige Plaza shopping center (Sta. 1303+00.00). The
length of the project would be extended to approximately 4500 feet. This
method of tying back into the existing condition meets NJDOT standards.
Though the proposed limits of Alternative 2A are different than those of
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
Alternative 2, there would be no significant change in LOS or delay. Due to
the lengthening of the project limits, there would be an increase in the
Construction Easement to a total of 2025 ft
. Due to the widening of the
roadway there will be a total of 16,812 ft
of disturbed area due to the construction footprint.
Based on a preliminary cost estimate, the construction costs for Alternative 2A
Table 21 illustrates the advantages and disadvantages for Alternative 2A.
Larger construction foot print which leads to
Thru lane “ends” as a right-turn only lane
Delays will quickly escalate on Route 31 at
Alternative 2A meets the needs of the project with minimal impacts and without
a substandard transition. However there were two concerns with this
alternative. First, it was felt that “dropping” the second through lane at the
Prestige Plaza where the right-turn lane starts would create a similar situation
to the current issue at Route 31 and Minneakoning Rd. Second, similar to
Alternative 2, this alternative does not have much flexibility in capacity at the
intersection of Route 31 and Prestige Plaza, so conditions on Route 31 could
quickly deteriorate if anticipated development occurs at Prestige Plaza.
Alternative 3 involves proposed improvements to the northbound side of Route
31 from the intersection of Route 31 at Minneakoning Road (Sta. 1258+00.00)
through the intersection of Route 31 and the Prestige Plaza shopping center
(1316+00.00). The length of the project would be extended to approximately
5800 feet. The proposed typical section consists of two twelve foot (12’) thru
lanes and a four foot (4’) shoulder. The typical section then transitions back to
the existing cross section of one twelve foot (12’) thru lane and an eight foot
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
This alternative will involve several R.O.W. impacts which include a permanent
). Due to the widening of the
roadway there will be 20,000 ft2 of additional impervious area and 15,981 ft
disturbed area due to the construction footprint.
Traffic analysis results for Alternative 3 are provided in Tables 22 and 23.

overall LOS and Delay as compared to existing conditions for the intersections
of Route 31 and Minneakoning Rd, Wescott Drive, and Bartles Corner Rd.
Unlike Alternatives 2 and 2A, Alternative 3 does not increase delay at Prestige
Plaza, which continues to operate well at LOS B.
Based on a preliminary cost estimate, the construction costs for Alternative 3

Flexibility to accommodate changes in traffic
Alternative 3 meets the needs of the project with minimal impacts, and
acceptable LOS and delay at all intersections. Additionally, Alternative 3
addresses the concerns expressed about Alternatives 2 and 2A as the second
thru lane continues through the intersection of Prestige Plaza and Route 31.
The four alternatives were evaluated based on their ability to meet the project
needs, their impacts to the existing conditions and capital costs. Based on the
advantages and disadvantages, each alternative addresses the needs to
certain levels. The determination was that the gains afforded by Alternative 3
outweighed the impacts of extending the project limits beyond the intersection
To capture the traffic results in a relative manner, Tables 25 and 26 contain
an improvement comparison of the LOS and Delay for existing conditions to
the alternatives for the AM and PM Peak Hours, respectively. The results
indicate that without widening through the intersection of Route 31 and Bartles
Corner Rd. (Alternative 2) increased delays will remain at the intersections of
Route 31 and Minneakoning Rd, Wescott Drive, and Bartles Corner Rd in the
PM Peak Hour for the existing 2007 traffic volumes.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza

page.text: NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
The IPA selected for this project is Alternative 3. Alternative 3 addresses the
project needs while providing more flexibility than Alternatives 2 and 2A and
addressing the design concerns/issues of those alternatives. The IPA involves
proposed improvements to the northbound side of Route 31 from the intersection of
Route 31 at Minneakoning Road (Sta. 1258+00.00) through the intersection of
Route 31 and the Prestige Plaza shopping center (1316+00.00). The length of the
project would approximately 5800 feet. The proposed typical section consists of two
twelve foot (12’) thru lanes and a four foot (4’) shoulder. The typical section then
transitions back to the existing cross section of one twelve foot (12’) thru lane and
Due to the widening of the roadway there will be 20,000 ft2 of additional impervious
area and 15,981 ft2 of disturbed area due to the construction footprint.
Based on a preliminary cost estimate, the construction costs for the IPA are
projected to be $1.8 Million. It should be noted that there are utility cost associated
with the IPA which may increase based upon the final construction layout. There is
a sewer line relocation associated with the IPA and at the time of this report a
decision on who is responsible for the relocation has yet to be determined. This
item could potentially increase the costs above the estimate of $1.8 Million.
The IPA has been illustrated graphically in Appendix M.
The horizontal and vertical alignments for the project were designed to adhere to
the minimum requirements set forth in the RDM while minimizing impacts to existing
properties. The project form for the Controlling Substandard Design Elements
along Route 31 has been included in Appendix N.
There are no changes or modification to the horizontal alignment of Route 31 in the
There are no changes or modification to the vertical alignment of Route 31 in the
The typical section throughout the IPA consists of two northbound lanes varying
between 11’ and 12’ with a minimum 4’ outside shoulder.

i.b: Discussion of Right of Way Impacts

page.text: There are limited R.O.W. impacts associated with the IPA. They include a
permanent drainage easement (490 ft2), permanent Utility Easement (1796 ft2),
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
and a temporary Construction Easement (2025 ft2). A summary of the anticipated
right-of-way impacts associated with each parcel as a result of the improvements
proposed under the IPA has been provided in Appendix O of this document.
There are no proposed structures within the limits of the project.
The IPA impacts 13 driveways (13 adjustments) within the project limits. A
summary of the access impacts associated with each parcel as a result of the
improvements proposed under the IPA has been provided in Appendix P of this
The proposed IPA does not necessitate changing the phasing at study area
intersections, although it is designed to provide adequate capacity if in the future
protected-only left-turn movements from Route 31 onto the side streets are
Although the project is intended to be a “quick fix”, the IPA was simulated with
future year volumes to determine its approximate lifespan. Horizon years of 2010,
2020 and 2035 were analyzed in Synchro/SimTraffic where a 1.0% average annual
compounded growth rate was applied to the 2007 existing volumes. The growth
rate was based on North Jersey Transportation Planning Authority (NJTPA)
demographic forecasts for Hunterdon County and Raritan Township which extend
to 2030. To account for future shopping center development at the Prestige Plaza
development, 130 vehicles (65 in/65 out) were added to the intersection of Route 31
and Prestige Plaza during the PM Peak Hour for all three horizon year scenarios.
Tables 27 and 28 show the results of the traffic analysis and indicate that the IPA
will operate at LOS D or better at all intersections for the 2010 and 2020 scenarios.
The analysis shows that some of the intersections are projected to operate at failing
conditions by 2035. It is worth noting that the northbound Route 31 movement is
not projected to fail for any time period.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza

i.b: Table 27: IPA Future AM Peak Hour Alternatives Summary Levels of Service and Delay
Table 28: IPA Future PM Peak Hour Alternatives Summary Levels of Service and Delay

page.text: Construction staging concepts have been considered for the IPA for this project. It
appears that the traffic can be maintained through the work area, without the use of
detour routes during construction of the improvements proposed under the IPA.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
The work can be completed in two stages. The major items of work to be
completed in each stage are described below:
Traffic on Route 31 will maintain its current pattern with the northbound lanes being
restricted by temporary traffic control devices.
Widening and full depth construction can be completed along the outside edge of
Traffic on Route 31 can be shifted onto the newly constructed pavement.
Resurfacing of the existing northbound lane will be completed during this phase.
As proposed in the IPA, the widening of the Route 31 would affect some of the
aerial utilities in the project area as well as signal equipment at certain intersections.
There are also inlets and manholes that would need to be relocated or reset to fit
This breakout project has several relatively small improvements over approximately
a one mile stretch of road, associated with four separate sub-drainage areas. The
added impervious coverage per sub-drainage area is individually less than 0.25
acres, but collectively more than 0.25 acres over the collective four sub-drainage
There are limited areas to implement compensatory stormwater controls due to right
of way limitations, and there is economy of scale in managing stormwater at
suitable and available sites where feasible. If necessary, compensatory water
quality controls in one sub-watershed may compensate for deficiency in another
sub-watershed under certain conditions. We have identified one location within the
right of way and sufficiently off set 50-feet from an adjacent stream, to comply with
the Riparian Zone requirements, which can manage about 0.44 acres of impervious
coverage off-setting the various improvements over this one mile road segment.
The figure titled Detention BMP Concept (Refer to Appendix R) shows the
prospective BMP Basin location, adjacent to the Wescott Drive and Route 31
intersection, including contours associated with three basins in series that has the
capacity to manage the contributing flow.
The runoff generated was modeled to enter a series of basis with a gabion wall to
limit disturbance within the existing right of way, and a gabion spillway to detain and
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
release water as a conventional detention basin. The preliminary analysis shows
that the basin has sufficient capacity to detain and manage the contributing runoff
with the following resulting reduction in peak flows. See Table 29 and Appendix R.

i.b: Table 29: Pre and Post Peak Flow Rate Summary, Preliminary Assessment

page.text: Geotechnical investigations of the project area were limited to the review of the
Base mapping for this project was developed utilizing scanned aerial photographs,
as built record plans, and a field survey. The scanned aerial photography was then
imported into the project design file utilizing CADD software and matched to fit the
topographic information gathered from the field survey.
A review of the NJDOT Pedestrian Compatible Planning and Design Guidelines
was conducted in the evaluation of this project. These guidelines indicate that for a
facility with a posted speed of 40 mph or a truck, bus, or recreational vehicle
percentage over 5%, paved shoulder widths beyond 4 feet are desirable and should
be considered for the pedestrian compatibility requirements. The portion of NJ
Route 31 within the project limits contains a shoulder width of at least 4 feet. This
portion of NJ Route 31 is therefore compatible.
The portion of NJ Route 31 within the project limits contains at least a 4 foot
shoulder. Therefore, this portion of NJ Route 31 is compatible.
There are no Context Sensitive Design items on this project.
This section of Route 31 was reconstructed as part of the Route 31 Section 6D
project which included Categorical Exclusion level documentation. Following
coordination with internal NJDOT Environmental Staff, the determination was made
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza
that an environmental screening was unnecessary due to the previous CED efforts
combined with the environmental coordination associated with the Flemington
Bypass and South Branch Parkway Projects.
The anticipated level of documentation will be CED.
As part of the process of selecting the IPA, DPD sought input from both internal and
external stakeholders through presentations and meetings. The project was
presented to the NJDOT Subject Matter Experts (SMEs) at a Core Group Meeting
on (09/24/09) and during follow-up meetings with smaller groups of SMEs to deal
with specific issues. The project was presented to the Raritan Township Local
Officials in June of 2009. The project was also presented to the Public Information
Center (PIC) on 12/14/09. A copy of the meeting minutes from the Core Group
Meeting and summary of the comments received during the PIC are provided in
During the PIC, there was a discussion regarding the lack of a right-turn lane in the
NB direction for the IPA into the BJ’s driveway (at Wescott Drive) access. Cyzner
Properties (Irv Cyzner) indicated that he owned parcels on either side of the
driveway. He indicated that the lack of a NB right-turn lane would adversely affect
his tenants. In response to the questions raised, NJDOT evaluated the traffic
operations with and without a NB right-turn lane. The results of the analysis
indicated that the addition of a NB right-turn lane would have little impact on the
operations. A copy of the analysis is provided in Appendix B.
Coordination efforts are on-going with Cyzner Properties. It is anticipated that this
issue will be resolved during final design.
A copy of the Township’s Resolution of Support has been provided in Appendix Q.

• Further coordination with Utility companies regarding their facilities and

No fatal flaws have been identified. A design exception for shoulder width is planned
and has been coordinated with NJDOT Subject Matter Experts for their concurrence.

text.b: Analyze and Approve Substandard Design Elements

page.text: In order to obtain Federal and Department approvals, a project must either conform
to the appropriate design standards or have approved design exceptions. Design
Exceptions may be approved when it can be demonstrated that compliance with the
standard will cause severe social, economic and/or environmental impacts and that
the Design Exceptions are in the interest of the Department, the traveling public and
The design exception report is comprised of three parts: a list of all CSDEs by
location number and station/milepost, a checklist of the impacts to meet the
standard value, and a table(s) containing a description of the CSDE including the
standard design value, the proposed safety measures, accident analysis, and the
Once the review of all the initial geometrics has been completed, the final Design
Exception report should be developed in consultation with the Project Manager and
submitted to Director, Division of Design Services

to be developed and a funding source is to be established by the NJDOT Utilities

Volume II – Section II of the Fiscal Year 2010 to 2019 STIP list Route 31, Church Street
to River Road (DB#08327) for PD in FY10. The Route 31 Northbound, Minneakoning
Road to M.P. 24.73 Project (DB# 08327A) was designated for advancement out of
parent project and was initiated after the STIP was finalized. This year’s DRAFT STIP
lists Route 31 Northbound, Minneakoning Road to M.P. 24.73 (DB# 08327A) for $1.2 M
CON (DEMO) in FY11. The DES will be funded primarily through a State funded Term
Agreement consultant in FY10 and FY11.
NJ Route 31 Northbound Improvements, Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza

text.b: VI Social, Economic and Environmental Considerations

page.text: The project will improve the northbound segment of NJ Route 31 from
Minneakoning Road through Prestige Plaza, specifically addressing the safety and
congestion concerns identified through the efforts that occurred during the Concept
Development phase of the NJDOT Project Delivery Process.
The completion of this project will generate a negative impact during construction
on the traveling public who uses NJ Route 31 and some minor impacts to the
surrounding environment. In the case of this project, both have been addressed
during the scoping process and should be minimized moving forward to design.
Through the process, an open communication has been developed between the
township and the NJDOT. As the project moves forward through design, this
This section of Route 31 was reconstructed as part of the Route 31 Section 6D
project which included Categorical Exclusion level documentation. Following
coordination with internal NJDOT Environmental Staff, the determination was made
that an environmental screening was unnecessary due to the previous CED efforts
combined with the environmental coordination associated with the Flemington
Bypass and South Branch Parkway Projects.
Consultation with SHPO was completed on 10/20/09 for the current CED effort.
The anticipated level of documentation will be CED.

text.b: VII Preliminary Cost Estimates for Project Development

page.text: The following are preliminary cost estimates for planning, scoping and design
Planning (100k – CD for entire Route 31 from Church Street to River Road
